body.p: Which of the following would provide even more convincing evidence that, indeed, P(B) is roughly 0.55?

multiple_choice.choice: Out of 10 randomly chosen college students, 5.5 reported that they had eaten breakfast that day.
Out of 20 randomly chosen college students, 11 reported that they had eaten breakfast that day.
Out of 1,000 randomly chosen college students, 850 reported that they had eaten breakfast that day.
Out of 1,000 randomly chosen college students, 550 reported that they had eaten breakfast that day.

response.feedback: 5.5 students? Is it possible for a fraction of a student to exist? Please try again.

Incorrect. While the relative frequency in this scenario is also 11 / 20 = 0.55, remember that the more repetitions that are performed, the closer the relative frequency gets to the probability it estimates. Here we perform only 20 repetitions, compared to 460 in the original survey. Please try again.
Incorrect. While it is true that we perform more repetitions here (1,000 vs. 460), the relative frequency here is 850 / 1,000 = 0.85, not 0.55. Please try again.
Correct. The relative frequency here (550 / 1,000 = 0.55) is based on a larger number of repetitions (1,000 vs. 460) and therefore provides a better estimate for P(B).
